content.question: A large block of mass <math alttext="m sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> on a horizontal table is attached to a small block of mass <math alttext="m sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> by a light string that hangs over a pulley of mass <math alttext="m sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, as shown. The table and pulley axle have negligible friction. The system is released from rest. As the blocks move, the string exerts tension <math alttext="F sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> on <math alttext="m sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math> and <math alttext="F sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>F</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> on <math alttext="m sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, as shown. If the pulley is replaced with a new pulley that has the same radius but a much larger mass, <math alttext="alpha" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>α</mi></math> is found to be smaller. If frictional forces are negligible, which of the following is the best explanation for this observation?
